content: yep, that's it. i noticed he has good conducts for army, navy and marines. back in the day, you had to serve 4 years active duty to get one.. they have since changed it (at least navy) to 3 years. but he tells me he served either a little, or less than 10 years. and if i remember right, aren't enlisted the only ones to get good conducts?
reply: yep, that's it. i noticed he has good conducts for army, navy and marines. back in the day, you had to serve 4 years active duty to get one.. they have since changed it (at least navy) to 3 years. but he tells me he served either a little, or less than 10 years. and if i remember right, aren't enlisted the only ones to get good conducts?

title: all four branches of the military?

content: quote: in all four branches There are five branches of the military, my daughter and granddaughter would like me if I didn't remind everyone that the Coast Guard is a branch of the military. We have a dear friend who served as an officer in all five branches. Here how how it went for him. He was an army ROTC graduate and received his commission in the army. He got out after three years and enrolled in seminary. The air force reserve accepted him so he could be a Chaplin for them and the CAP during his seminary days. However upon receiving his doctorate the AF didn't have an open slot for his denominations.. You guessed it, the navy did. Because he was a cavalry line officer in army the navy detailed him to the marines for his first duty assignment. He landed with the marines during desert storm. When he returned the chief of chaplains for the navy realized as he stated it "A once in a life time opportunity and ask him how he would feel about having another uniform in his sea bag." he accepted, of course, and was detailed to the Coast Guard. About ten years ago, he retired as a navy-captain chaplain at Paris Island with 30 years active duty. There was a big story about him in the military time, all of them. I think it said he it was only the third person since some time before WW2 to serve as an officer in all five branches, If you dig deep enough you can find the story. I don’t have his permission to share his name. The coast guard and marine use the navy chaplains. A listening ear, a caring heart, an open mind and an extend hand may be all I can offer, but they are yours without charge or judgment.
quote: in all four branches
reply: There are five branches of the military, my daughter and granddaughter would like me if I didn't remind everyone that the Coast Guard is a branch of the military. We have a dear friend who served as an officer in all five branches. Here how how it went for him. He was an army ROTC graduate and received his commission in the army. He got out after three years and enrolled in seminary. The air force reserve accepted him so he could be a Chaplin for them and the CAP during his seminary days. However upon receiving his doctorate the AF didn't have an open slot for his denominations.. You guessed it, the navy did. Because he was a cavalry line officer in army the navy detailed him to the marines for his first duty assignment. He landed with the marines during desert storm. When he returned the chief of chaplains for the navy realized as he stated it "A once in a life time opportunity and ask him how he would feel about having another uniform in his sea bag." he accepted, of course, and was detailed to the Coast Guard. About ten years ago, he retired as a navy-captain chaplain at Paris Island with 30 years active duty. There was a big story about him in the military time, all of them. I think it said he it was only the third person since some time before WW2 to serve as an officer in all five branches, If you dig deep enough you can find the story. I don’t have his permission to share his name. The coast guard and marine use the navy chaplains. A listening ear, a caring heart, an open mind and an extend hand may be all I can offer, but they are yours without charge or judgment.

content: quote: Originally posted by OldArmyWOPA: quote: in all four branches There are five branches of the military, my daughter and granddaughter would like me if I didn't remind everyone that the Coast Guard is a branch of the military. Not any more. Today, the Coast Guard is part of the Dept. of Homeland Security. In the past, they were with the Treasury Department.
quote: Originally posted by OldArmyWOPA: quote: in all four branches There are five branches of the military, my daughter and granddaughter would like me if I didn't remind everyone that the Coast Guard is a branch of the military.
reply: Not any more. Today, the Coast Guard is part of the Dept. of Homeland Security. In the past, they were with the Treasury Department.

content: quote: in all four branches There are five branches of the military, my daughter and granddaughter would like me if I didn't remind everyone that the Coast Guard is a branch of the military. We have a dear friend who served as an officer in all five branches. Here how how it went for him. He was an army ROTC graduate and received his commission in the army. He got out after three years and enrolled in seminary. The air force reserve accepted him so he could be a Chaplin for them and the CAP during his seminary days. However upon receiving his doctorate the AF didn't have an open slot for his denominations.. You guessed it, the navy did. Because he was a cavalry line officer in army the navy detailed him to the marines for his first duty assignment. He landed with the marines during desert storm. When he returned the chief of chaplains for the navy realized as he stated it "A once in a life time opportunity and ask him how he would feel about having another uniform in his sea bag." he accepted, of course, and was detailed to the Coast Guard. About ten years ago, he retired as a navy-captain chaplain at Paris Island with 30 years active duty. There was a big story about him in the military time, all of them. I think it said he it was only the third person since some time before WW2 to serve as an officer in all five branches, If you dig deep enough you can find the story. I don’t have his permission to share his name. The coast guard and marine use the navy chaplains. A listening ear, a caring heart, an open mind and an extend hand may be all I can offer, but they are yours without charge or judgment.
quote: in all four branches
reply: There are five branches of the military, my daughter and granddaughter would like me if I didn't remind everyone that the Coast Guard is a branch of the military. We have a dear friend who served as an officer in all five branches. Here how how it went for him. He was an army ROTC graduate and received his commission in the army. He got out after three years and enrolled in seminary. The air force reserve accepted him so he could be a Chaplin for them and the CAP during his seminary days. However upon receiving his doctorate the AF didn't have an open slot for his denominations.. You guessed it, the navy did. Because he was a cavalry line officer in army the navy detailed him to the marines for his first duty assignment. He landed with the marines during desert storm. When he returned the chief of chaplains for the navy realized as he stated it "A once in a life time opportunity and ask him how he would feel about having another uniform in his sea bag." he accepted, of course, and was detailed to the Coast Guard. About ten years ago, he retired as a navy-captain chaplain at Paris Island with 30 years active duty. There was a big story about him in the military time, all of them. I think it said he it was only the third person since some time before WW2 to serve as an officer in all five branches, If you dig deep enough you can find the story. I don’t have his permission to share his name. The coast guard and marine use the navy chaplains. A listening ear, a caring heart, an open mind and an extend hand may be all I can offer, but they are yours without charge or judgment.

One Flag......One Heart......One Nation............EVERMORE
title: all four branches of the military?

content: quote: in all four branches There are five branches of the military, my daughter and granddaughter would like me if I didn't remind everyone that the Coast Guard is a branch of the military. We have a dear friend who served as an officer in all five branches. Here how how it went for him. He was an army ROTC graduate and received his commission in the army. He got out after three years and enrolled in seminary. The air force reserve accepted him so he could be a Chaplin for them and the CAP during his seminary days. However upon receiving his doctorate the AF didn't have an open slot for his denominations.. You guessed it, the navy did. Because he was a cavalry line officer in army the navy detailed him to the marines for his first duty assignment. He landed with the marines during desert storm. When he returned the chief of chaplains for the navy realized as he stated it "A once in a life time opportunity and ask him how he would feel about having another uniform in his sea bag." he accepted, of course, and was detailed to the Coast Guard. About ten years ago, he retired as a navy-captain chaplain at Paris Island with 30 years active duty. There was a big story about him in the military time, all of them. I think it said he it was only the third person since some time before WW2 to serve as an officer in all five branches, If you dig deep enough you can find the story. I don’t have his permission to share his name. The coast guard and marine use the navy chaplains. A listening ear, a caring heart, an open mind and an extend hand may be all I can offer, but they are yours without charge or judgment.
quote: in all four branches

content: On the yahoo group site, he claims to have "Brugada Disease" which is actually Brugada Syndrome. This is a form of arrhythmia, so wouldn't that have been a medical disqualification for service?

content: quote: Originally posted by OldArmyWOPA: quote: in all four branches There are five branches of the military, my daughter and granddaughter would like me if I didn't remind everyone that the Coast Guard is a branch of the military. Not any more. Today, the Coast Guard is part of the Dept. of Homeland Security. In the past, they were with the Treasury Department.
quote: Originally posted by OldArmyWOPA: quote: in all four branches There are five branches of the military, my daughter and granddaughter would like me if I didn't remind everyone that the Coast Guard is a branch of the military.
reply: Not any more. Today, the Coast Guard is part of the Dept. of Homeland Security. In the past, they were with the Treasury Department.
